Hi, Iâ€™m Lorenzo.

Iâ€™ve been thinking about writing for a long time, and I finally decided to publish this blog.
Not to be â€œa creatorâ€ or something like that â€” just to keep track of what I learn and share it with whoever finds it useful.

## What you will find here

Mostly things around software and the life around it:

- software engineering stuff I face in real projects (architecture, scalability, reliability, messy trade-offs)
- notes about tools / workflows that I actually use
- remote work life (I work from Sicily, sometimes literally with the sea in front)
- learning experiments (Rust, infra, random deep dives)
- and sometimes personal things: family, time, balance, small projects

I donâ€™t have a fixed schedule. Iâ€™ll write when I have something real to say.

## Why Iâ€™m doing it now

In the last years I built a lot, broke a lot, fixed a lot.
I also changed life (moved, family, new priorities). Writing helps me slow down and put things in order.

Also: many times I solve a problem and then I forget the details after 2 months. This blog is also for future-me.

A journey through code, curiosity, and creativity

## Hello world! Hi! Iâ€™m Lorenzo Iovino. Iâ€™m a Software Engineer (thatâ€™s my job), but I donâ€™t like to define myself only with a role title. Iâ€™m a curious person and I always jump between code, ideas, and side passions. I was born in December 1988 and since then Iâ€™ve been basically chasing two things: understanding how things work, and building things that are useful (or just fun). This page is a small recap of my story. Nothing special, just me. ## Childhood Nostalgia
Super young software developer with an Apple II
My first â€œwowâ€ moment with computers was very early. I was around 4 years old and I was playing Prince of Persia on an Apple II. From that moment, computers never really left my life. Today they are my work, but also the main thing I enjoy. I grew up in Ispica, in the south of Sicily. My days were simple: school, videogames, and football with friends. Honestly, it was a good life. Ispica is slow, warm, and beautiful. When I was a kid I didnâ€™t see it that way. I wanted to escape. I was dreaming about big cities, more people, more things happening, more opportunities.
Pokemon Yellow and Game Boy Advance
Then came Pokemon, Nintendo consoles, and long afternoons with friends. And at some point, I started to get curious about what was â€œbehindâ€ games and computers. That curiosity slowly became programming. When I was 15 I discovered rock music and it hit me hard. I bought a guitar and I started learning (very badly at the beginning) but I loved it.
My dream guitar "Fender stratocaster"
Games + music = I became a classic nerd. I wanted to understand computers, programming languages, and all the â€œmagicâ€ under the hood. At 17 I also discovered Magic: The Gathering. It became another obsession for a while. I still play sometimes, just for fun. ## University and Personal Growth I studied Computer Science at the University of Pisa. It was not a straight path.
Me burning out studying Computability and Complexity exam
I read a lot (often not the books suggested by professors), I failed exams, I repeated exams, I took online courses, I attended workshopsâ€¦ I was trying to understand what â€œcomputer scienceâ€ really is. And yes, I still have mixed feelings about Computability and Complexity. ðŸ˜… It took me 12 years to finish my Bachelor. Not proud of the timeline, but Iâ€™m proud I didnâ€™t quit. Moving to Pisa was not only about studying. It was also my first real â€œlife outside Sicilyâ€ experience, and I needed that.
My student hat (that's not a hat) "goliardo"
University years for me were also: meeting people, spending time around the city, goliardia culture, wine sommelier course (yes), concerts, small music clubs, and long talks with strangers during aperitivo. That period also started my love for traveling. Seeing different cultures in real life changes your brain. ## Embarking on Hackathon Adventures
Me wearing moverio smart glasses
My first hackathon was organized by [Vargroup](https://www.vargroup.it/). We were a random team: nobody knew each other. But in 24 hours we built a Proof of Concept + a business idea for a retail app for furniture. It was made for Epson Moverio Smartglass: the idea was to let people â€œplaceâ€ furniture in their home in a virtual way. That experience made me addicted to hackathons. After that I joined other events like Hackaton Toscana (mobility) and also some game jams. Every time you learn something new, and you also learn a lot about teamwork under pressure.
Me and the team presenting the game developed
*Gameplay of our game "Oh No My Husband is coming" developed for GGJ 2015: [Youtube link](https://www.youtube.com/embed/z1Kn6agAujI)* ## Erasmus Project in Valencia
Beautiful sunny day in Valencia
A big turning point was my Erasmus in Valencia. I kept studying Computer Science at Universidad Politecnica, met people from everywhere, and got exposed to different cultures and languages. The tech environment there felt different compared to Italy. In that period there was a lot of energy: startups, new ideas, and a strong feeling that people wanted to build things. Valencia also helped me grow as a person. New country, new habits, new friends, new perspective. ## Embracing the Tranquility of Sicily At some point I decided to go back to Sicily. Not as a â€œI give upâ€ move. More like: I want a different balance.
Working remote watching the sea
I lived the fast pace, the rush, the always-online mindset. Coming back here was intentional: less noise, more space, more time. I work remote, and Sicily is perfect for that. Life is slower. Sometimes itâ€™s frustrating, but often itâ€™s exactly what I need. Time here feels different. You can actually breathe. You can have â€œnothing specialâ€ days, and those days can still feel good.
My wineyard
Family is a big part of my life here. And I also started a side project with my sister (sheâ€™s an agronomist): we planted a small vineyard near the sea and we started producing our own wine. That project became [www.netum.it](https://netum.it/). Itâ€™s small (1 hectare), limited bottles, but itâ€™s something we built together and I love it.
The wine produced "Zia Lina"
And yes: food. Sicily is crazy for food. Itâ€™s not even a â€œfood cultureâ€, itâ€™s basically a religion. *(No food photos here. Iâ€™m not a food blogger. But trust me.)* For me, living here is a reminder: success is not only about projects and code. Itâ€™s also about how you live your days.
Modica view from my house
## Life at 35 Today Iâ€™m a husband (to my wife Amanda) and a dad (to our little Leonardo). Life changed a lot, in a good way. I still love technology, I still build things, but family gives a different meaning to everything.
Me and my wife Amanda
